data.title: The screen stuck for a while after you come back from a long-locked windows screen.
data.body:
Hi Daniel,
 I met a problem for handling the lost device context issue. After I started my game and then locked my windows for a period of time(such as 1 hour or more) and unlocked it, all the textures of my game would be recovered, everything  went well until I put a lot of particles on screen, the screen would be stuck for a split second(or many seconds, sometimes the FPS would just drop to 1-2) then return to normal(some frames skipped) every time if big amount of particles appeared, this would not happen if I don't lock my computer,  this would also not happen if there is not much particles. 
Have you had any idea on this? Thanks!

data.title: QuadBatch: tinted/untinted quads might deteriorate performances
data.body:
Hi Daniel,
I noticed that although your new management of untinted quads might improve performances for cases where none of the quads are tinted, this might also deteriorate the performances whenever there is a mix of tinted and not tinted quads.
It breaks indeed what would have previously been put in a single batch into multiple batches... In the worse case where you have one tinted quad in between 2 untinted quads on a long list of quads, this deteriorates a lot the performances...

We'll need to potentially rearrange our children list not to mix tinted and untinted. There might be a need to post some hint about it on the Wiki don't you think ?

Cheers.

data.title: Add skewX and skewY to DisplayObject
data.body:
This takes advantage of the fact that a rotation is a skew where both skewX and skewY angles are equal.

(3afaa093 and 9f9aa184 are the changes. The other XML commits couldn't be easily removed from this pull request, so feel free to ignore them)

data.title: ParticleSystem.as, Incorrect number of arguments
data.body:
Hi,

I Just downloaded the latest revision and there seems to be a problem on line 287 of ParticleSystem.as

mVertexData.setColor(vertexID+j, color, alpha);

There's no longer an alpha argument needed.

Thanks,
bas

data.title: Blurring / bleeding of persistent RenderTexture
data.body:
This issue was solved by Jeff in the Starling forum. See the thread below for a complete description, pictures and a video of what was happening, along with Jeff's solution.

http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/strange-rendertexture-bleeding-blurring-on-ipad

Thanks.

data.title: Persistent touches when pressing HOME while touching on iPhone
data.body:
When you are holding a touch on the screen, press HOME, stop touching, re-enter the application and touch anywhere, you will have two touches: The new one, and the old one as "stationary". The old one is persistent. This is stackable. (And also really annoying.)

Here is a minimal example project reproducing the problem: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/1977054/temp/DemoStationaryTouch.zip

Steps to reproduce:
1. Hold and/or move a touch anywhere
2. Continue holding the touch and press HOME
3. Stop holding the touch
4. Go back into the application
5. Touch anywhere

Rinse and repeat.

You will see the old touches that didn't end before you pressed HOME as "stationary" whenever you touch the screen again.

We are using AIR 3.2 and Starling 1.0. Switching to the current version on GitHUB (v1.1 23.04.2012) didn't fix the problem either.

It would be great if you could check it out fast. The game we are making is very near to its release, and every time iOS gets interrupted (for example due to an incoming call, battery low notification or the HOME button) the game becomes unusable until restarted.

data.title: any Touch related must be separate
data.body:
IMHO any touch related must have it own  library separated from Starling
I'm saying this because i did separate it and use it with normal 2D app (without Stage3D need)
the pro for this is i do save my plenty of time to test touch on real device and use fake touch from Starling via simulator instead
which mean it can be separate for no need touch app for smaller size and/or even can be use with normal 2D app

In short
Please separate Touch related as another library so it can be use with other app with/with out Stage3D need

data.title: TextField doesn't dispose m_image when updating lead to a text texture reached 4096 limitation problem
data.body: This problem happened before and you get it fixed, but it seems that you remove the dispose operation of m_image in redrawContents function, so the same issue will happen again.

data.title: Make sure touch always starts in HOVER or BEGAN phase
data.body:
In a special situation (when the target of a touch was removed from the stage within the touch event), a touch will be dispatched at a target with a MOVED or ENDED phase; the object will not have seen a HOVER or BEGAN phase. This could be confusing and lead to hard to find bugs.

Here is the discussion that caused me to introduce the bug:
http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/hover-events-stuck-on-dead-display-object

And here is the discussion that lead to this issue:
https://github.com/PrimaryFeather/Starling-Framework/commit/2fc84e3da3cf181606abfd093d365af9490cb864#commitcomment-1094368

data.title: Include getRegion(textureName:String):Rectangle in TextureAtlas
data.body: Because starling does not store bitmapdata information, if you need that data for anything (like hit detection) you need to store it somewhere.  This is fine but in the case ofusing  a TextureAtlas you also need the region information to know which bitmapdata your are using.  You could parse the Atlas XML yourself but since the information already exists inside the TextureAtlas class it would make sense to expose it.

data.title: QuadBatch compileObject issue
data.body:
Hi,

it seems to me there is a bug with the current QuadBatch code:
if you call the compileObject method on an object that is also a QuadBatch, the current code increments the quadBatchID and push the new QuadBatch to the list of quadBatches.

The issue is that if the current QuadBatch is empty, a call to compileObject on a new QuadBatch results in leaving this current empty QuadBatch in the list and adding the new one after it. Unfortunately there is an exception when attempting to render an empty QuadBatch because of a null index buffer.

This is reproducible when calling flatten on a Sprite for which the first child is a TextField.

Fix proposal:
- if the current QuadBatch in empty, fill it by the content of QuadBatch object provided as the argument of the compileObject method (or eventually replace it by the clone)

As a bonus, it would be excellent to merge the current QuadBatch with the new one if they are compatible. For instance, a sprite full of TextField all sharing the same BitmapFont / blendmode... could be flattened into a single QuadBatch !

Let me know your thoughts.

Cheers.

data.title: Text with QuadBatch needs to handle lost contexts
data.body:
Daniel,  maybe you missed this on the forums, so I am adding this as an issue (originally from Josh) just to be sure you do :)

http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/text-with-quadbatch-and-handle-lost-context

data.title: Missing font files
data.body:
Looks like mini.fnt and mini.png are missing from the assets dir.
( They are embedded in the BitmapFont class )

Cheers,
bas

data.title: Make tweens object pool friendly
QuadBatch.compileObject doesn't support QuadBatches that are used as display objects
data.body: Throws an "Unsupported display object" error when I try to flatten.

data.title: MovieClip max frame crash
data.body:
I'm getting an error with the latest version of Starling from GIT in MovieClip on this line:
while (mCurrentTime >= mStartTimes[mCurrentFrame] + mDurations[mCurrentFrame])

In my application, mStartTimes has 63 items and mDurations has 64 items. The report from numFrames states that there should be 64 frames in the animation.

The error is that mStartTimes[63] will crash as the maximum index is 62; despite that mDurations and numFrames seem to be correct.

To initialize this MovieClip, I'm using the addFrameAt method for popping frames in before the game starts.

Posted on http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/movieclip-max-frame-problem before I knew this issue tracker existed.

data.title: Add support to rotated sprites in SpriteAtlas created from TexturePacker
data.body: This issue is important to reduce  the space of spriteatlases images. Consist in the possibility of save individual sprites in the atlas with a rotation degree (multiply of 90 degrees), It permit compact the sprites in the atlas still more.

data.title: Texture.fromBitmapData data/potData references
data.body:
This may be a non-issue, but the code strikes me as potentially dangerous so I thought I'd bring it up just for a sanity check.

In starling.textures.Texture.fromBitmapData(), there is code that checks if the passed in data:BitmapData is a POT size and if not, a new BitmapData instance of the appropriate size is created as potData and pixels copied in.

However, then the code reassigns the value of data to potData on line 136.
Is this not a pass-by-reference argument that would then affect the original bitmapData (also one that might be living in a Bitmap called from the Texture.fromBitmap?)
Maybe my understanding of local references to function arguments is off here for ActionScript.

I was also wondering that you do a potData.dispose as well if not handling lost context which would then nullify the bitmapData passed in since the data reference was reassigned to potData as well.

data.title: New Event: starling.events.Event.ROOT_CREATED
data.body:
Since Starling is founded on the instantiation of a RootClass, it's important for listeners outside Starling to know when the instance of that RootClass is available. And because Starling both creates and adds that instance to stage, there's no determinative way to know this has occurred at present. I've added a dispatch from Starling.initializeRoot(). This Event occurs after rootObject is added to Stage, so it effectively informs listeners that Starling is safe to interact with.

Arguably there should be two Events: one when the rootObject is created and a second when rootObject is added to stage. This would let a listener perform actions between those two Events. I'll leave it to you to determine if the extra event is useful, but I'm reasonably certain that at least the code I've provided is beneficial.

data.title: Add a property similar to mouseChildren
data.body:
mouseChildren = false stops children from dispatching mouse events, but it allows their parent to continue to use their hit areas to dispatch its own mouse events. Something like this in Starling would be useful for two reasons:

1) The touch processing seems to use a lot of CPU. My Scale9Image class in Foxhole needs to have nine children. Put enough of those on stage, and any touch activity will noticeably affect FPS. I don't really care if the mouse is specifically over one of the nine children, but I may want their parent to be touchable.

2) In the thread below from the forums, someone is trying to access a Sprite that contains the touch target, but is deeper in the display list than the event's currentTarget (the stage, in this case). In the classic display list, they could set mouseChildren = false to make this particular Sprite the target, but there's nothing similar in Starling.

http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/touch-not-working

data.title: ArgumentError: Object not connected to target
data.body:
Hi,

Since a recent change (that I cannot pinpoint exactly). It seems you have introduced a bug.

I think this is the scenario to reproduce:

Add a touch event callback to an object A "below" (i'm not sure it's important) another one, object B.
In this callback, you'll remove object B.
Since the event are processed in the same loop that traverse the objects hierarchy, the callback remove the object, but it's still processed in the loop, but since it's removed from it's parent, getTransformationMatrix will fail.

Exception fault: ArgumentError: Object not connected to target
    at starling.display::DisplayObject/getTransformationMatrix()[...Starling-Framework/starling/src/starling/display/DisplayObject.as:222]

Good luck :)

data.title: Error #2183 Sprite.flatten() child with scaleX or scaleY = 0
Fix an issue with FDT
data.body:
Hi,

When using FDT on my mac, it could not compile because it was messing up somehow between starling's Texture class and flash's Texture class.
This commit fix it by specifying more precisely wich kind of texture to use.

Thanks!

data.title: Textfield -> redrawContents NULL object
Optimized contains()
data.body: I changed contains() to search upwards from the child rather than downwards from the container. Instead of potentially looping over many branches of display objects, it's now a straight line of .parent references up to the stage.

data.title: Some optimizations.
data.body:
We have made some optimizations that helped us push our FPS higher on our lower end machines.  We thank you for your work on Starling, and would love it if our changes could be considered for a pull :).

Please feel free to contact me with any questions:
jote.sandhu@gmail.com

-TS AS3 Team

data.title: Minor bug in Image.smoothing function
data.body:
Ever so minor bug, but in the Image.smoothing method that checks for valid TextureSmoothing values
if the value is invalid the code throws an exception but uses the wrong argument to the exception message.

It is using the existing property value of the Image 'smoothing' when it should instead be reporting the invalid passed in value 'value'

data.title: Add antiAliasing as an optional Starling constructor arg
data.body:
I realize the list of arguments to Starling constructor is getting quite large, but the potential benefit of allowing antiAliasing in the constructor is to avoid unnecessary multiple calls to updateViewPort() and subsequently calls to context.configureBackBuffer().

Unless it is deemed that multiple calls to context.configureBackBuffer() isn't that expensive (though it seems to be hinted on AIR docs that it should be avoided) we can leave as is.

On startup, most apps are going to pick and set a single antiAliasing value for Starling/context3D and not change it dynamically,
but even if set directly after calling the Starling constructor (and because the constructor makes the requestContext3D call) setting starling.antiAliasing is going to force a second context.configureBackBuffer() call.

data.title: Expose enableDepthAndStencil property
data.body: In order to facilitate mixing Starling with other 3d rendered effects, it would be greatly beneficial to be able to control whether enableDepthAndStencil is set on the underlying context. By adding a boolean property to starling (defaulting to false, of course), updateViewPort would create back buffer with depth buffers. 3d content can then be mixed in via specially crafted extensions for those who want to do such things. This would be very similar to the behavior of the current mAntiAliasing property on Starling.

data.title: Expose baseline in BitmapFont
data.body: There's an attribute called "base" in the <common/> element of the XML files created by BMFont. This is the text baseline, and it's good info to have on hand for layout.
